verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, 'Build me seven altars here, and prepare for me seven bulls and seven rams.'
verses.comment: Balaam requests the building of seven altars, reflecting the importance of complete offerings. The idea of liturgical offerings bears spiritual significance as a prefigurement of ordered worship in the New Covenant (see Heb. 13:10).

verses.text: Balak did just as Balaam had spoken, and Balak and Balaam offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: The repeated act of offering sacrifices demonstrates a pattern reminiscent of priestly mediation—an idea that foreshadows the concept of a mediator between God and man (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: And Balaam said to Balak, 'Stay beside your burnt offering, and I will go; perhaps the LORD will meet me, and whatever He reveals to me, I will tell you.' So Balaam went to a barren height.
verses.comment: Balaam acts as an intermediary, seeking revelation from the LORD. The idea of ascending a height for divine encounter recalls Moses’ encounters with God (see Ex. 19:20).

verses.text: God met Balaam, and Balaam said to Him, 'I have prepared the seven altars, and I have offered a bull and a ram on each altar.'
verses.comment: God personally engages Balaam, showing the sovereignty of God over all people. God's direct address highlights true revelation comes only from Him.

verses.text: The LORD put a word in Balaam's mouth and said, 'Return to Balak, and this is what you shall say.'
verses.comment: The LORD's control of Balaam's message demonstrates prophetic inspiration; Balaam cannot speak except what God commands (cf. Jer. 1:9).

verses.text: So he returned to him, and behold, Balak was standing beside his burnt offering, he and all the officials of Moab.
verses.comment: Balak waits in confidence that Balaam’s power can be used for his own purposes, highlighting human attempts to manipulate the divine. Contrast with the biblical pattern of humble waiting (Ps. 27:14).

verses.text: Then Balaam took up his oracle and said: 'From Aram Balak has brought me, the king of Moab from the eastern mountains: "Come, curse Jacob for me, and come, denounce Israel!"'
verses.comment: The reference to 'Jacob' and 'Israel' affirms the special status of God’s chosen people, a motif continued throughout salvation history.

verses.text: 'How shall I curse whom God has not cursed? How can I denounce whom the LORD has not denounced?'
verses.comment: Only God has the authority to bless or curse. Balaam acknowledges the divine prerogative, anticipating themes of God’s sovereign election in the New Testament.

verses.text: 'For from the top of the rocks I see him, from the hills I observe him. Behold, a people dwelling apart, and not reckoning itself among the nations.'
verses.comment: Israel’s separation foreshadows the unique calling of God's people to be holy and set apart (1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: 'Who can count the dust of Jacob or number even a fourth of Israel? Let me die the death of the upright, and let my end be like his!'
verses.comment: Balaam longs for an inheritance with the righteous, prefiguring the hope of eternal life and the resurrection promised to the faithful (John 11:25).

verses.text: And Balak said to Balaam, 'What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, but look, you have blessed them altogether!'
verses.comment: Balak’s disappointment highlights the futility of opposing God's blessing, which flows from divine initiative, not human intention.

verses.text: And he answered and said, 'Must I not speak what the LORD puts in my mouth?'
verses.comment: Prophetic ministry is about obedience to God rather than appeasing human authority, foreshadowing apostolic fidelity (see Acts 5:29).

verses.text: Then Balak said to him, 'Please come with me to another place from which you may see them—you will see only a part of them and not all; curse them for me from there.'
verses.comment: Balak thinks changing position can change God’s will, misunderstanding the omnipresence and steadfastness of God.

verses.text: And he took him to the field of Zophim, to the top of Pisgah, and built seven altars, and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: The repetition of ritual acts without internal devotion cannot move God, anticipating later prophetic critiques of empty sacrifice (Isa. 1:11).

verses.text: And he said to Balak, 'Stand here beside your burnt offering while I go to meet with Him over there.'
verses.comment: Again, Balaam operates as an intermediary. The pattern of standing beside offerings while awaiting divine revelation prefigures later forms of liturgical worship.

verses.text: And the LORD met Balaam and put a word in his mouth, and said, 'Return to Balak, and this is what you shall say.'
verses.comment: Divine inspiration permeates true prophecy, highlighting authenticity measured by fidelity to God’s word, not personal agenda.

verses.text: So he came to Balak, and there he was, standing beside his burnt offering, and the officials of Moab with him. Balak said to him, 'What has the LORD spoken?'
verses.comment: Even pagan rulers are compelled to hear the word of the LORD, demonstrating the authority of true prophecy over all nations.

verses.text: Then Balaam took up his oracle and said: 'Rise up, Balak, and hear! Listen to me, O son of Zippor!'
verses.comment: Balaam calls Balak to hear God’s word with authority, prefiguring the biblical command to listen to God’s appointed messengers (Matt. 17:5).

verses.text: God is not a man, that He should lie, or a son of man, that He should change His mind. Has He said, and will He not do it? Or has He spoken, and will He not fulfill it?
verses.comment: The immutability and truthfulness of God are asserted here. What God promises, He will accomplish—vital for understanding the reliability of all God’s covenants.

verses.text: Look, I have received a command to bless; He has blessed, and I cannot revoke it.
verses.comment: When God blesses, no power can reverse it. Reflects God’s irrevocable gifts and calling (Rom. 11:29).

verses.text: He has not seen iniquity in Jacob, nor has He observed trouble in Israel. The LORD their God is with them, and the shout of a king is among them.
verses.comment: God's presence with His people is the root of their blessing. The 'shout of a king' hints at future messianic kingship.

verses.text: God brought them out of Egypt; He has strength like a wild ox.
verses.comment: God’s mighty deeds in deliverance are compared with the strength of a wild ox, a symbol of power. This alludes to the redemption accomplished for Israel, and ultimately fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:68).

verses.text: For there is no enchantment against Jacob, no divination against Israel; now it shall be said of Jacob and of Israel, 'What has God done!'
verses.comment: The effectiveness of God’s blessing renders all magic powerless, and the focus shifts to God’s mighty deeds, not human manipulation.

verses.text: Behold, a people rises up like a lioness, and lifts itself up like a lion; it does not lie down until it devours the prey and drinks the blood of the slain.'
verses.comment: The lion imagery points to the messianic title, 'the Lion of Judah' (Rev. 5:5), an anticipation of Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: Then Balak said to Balaam, 'Neither curse them at all, nor bless them at all!'
verses.comment: Balak’s frustration underlines that human authority is powerless against God's will.

verses.text: But Balaam answered and said to Balak, 'Did I not tell you, "All that the LORD speaks, that I must do"?'
verses.comment: Balaam insists on fidelity to the LORD’s command—a model for obedience.

verses.text: Balak said to Balaam, 'Come, I will take you to another place; perhaps it will please God that you may curse them for me from there.'
verses.comment: Balak continues to misunderstand God's unchanging will, supposing a change of place can affect the outcome.

verses.text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, overlooking the wasteland.
verses.comment: Peor later becomes known for Israel’s temptation (see Num. 25). Here, it is another futile attempt to manipulate God.

verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, 'Build seven altars for me here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.'
verses.comment: The persistent pattern of seven sacrifices highlights the number of completeness and the desire for perfect communion with the divine.

verses.text: Balak did as Balaam said and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: Though external acts of worship are repeated, inner disposition and obedience to God’s will are what truly matter. This anticipates the spiritual worship called for in the New Testament (Rom. 12:1).
